content.title: Money Supply
content.definition: The money supply is the total stock of money circulating in an economy at a given time, measured through monetary aggregates of varying liquidity. The most common measures are M1 (currency + checkable deposits, the most liquid), M2 (M1 + savings deposits, money market funds, small time deposits), and the monetary base (MB = currency + bank reserves, which the central bank directly controls). The relationship between the monetary base and broader money supply is determined by the money multiplier, which depends on reserve requirements and the public's currency preferences.

definitions_glossary.money_supply: Total stock of money (currency, deposits, other liquid assets) in an economy - measured by M1, M2, etc.
definitions_glossary.monetary_base: MB = Currency in circulation + Bank reserves - the 'high-powered money' directly controlled by central bank
definitions_glossary.m1: M1 = Currency + Demand deposits + Other checkable deposits + Traveler's checks - most liquid money measure
definitions_glossary.m2: M2 = M1 + Savings deposits + Small time deposits (<$100K) + Retail money market funds - broader liquidity measure
definitions_glossary.m3: M3 = M2 + Large time deposits + Institutional money market funds + Repurchase agreements (discontinued by Fed in 2006)
definitions_glossary.currency_in_circulation: Paper bills and coins held by the public (not in bank vaults) - most liquid form of money
definitions_glossary.demand_deposits: Checking account balances withdrawable on demand without notice - transactional money
definitions_glossary.reserves: Deposits held by commercial banks at the central bank + vault cash - required and excess reserves
definitions_glossary.required_reserve_ratio: Fraction of deposits banks must hold as reserves (rr) - set by central bank (was 10% in US, now 0% since March 2020)
definitions_glossary.excess_reserves: Reserves held beyond required amount - banks choose based on opportunity cost vs safety
definitions_glossary.money_multiplier: m = M1/MB ≈ (1+c)/(rr+c) where c is currency ratio - how monetary base translates to money supply
definitions_glossary.velocity_of_money: V = (P×Y)/M - how often money turns over; relates money supply to nominal GDP via equation of exchange
definitions_glossary.quantity_theory: MV = PY (equation of exchange) - foundation of monetarism linking money supply to price level

key_points: Monetary aggregates measure money supply: M1 (liquid), M2 (broader), MB (base money central bank controls directly)
US M1 ≈ $18 trillion, M2 ≈ $21 trillion (2024) - M2 includes less liquid savings/money market deposits
Money multiplier: M = m × MB where m = 1/rr (simple) or m = (1+c)/(rr+c) with currency ratio c
Central bank controls MB through open market operations, but M1/M2 depend on bank lending behavior and public preferences
Fractional reserve banking: Banks hold fraction as reserves, lend rest → creates deposits → expands money supply
Since March 2020, US reserve requirement is 0% - banks can lend all deposits (but still hold reserves for liquidity)
Quantity theory: MV = PY. If V stable, money supply growth → proportional price level growth (inflation)
Velocity not constant: Falls during crises (people hoard money), varies with financial innovation and interest rates
Money demand: Md/P = L(Y, r) - people demand real money balances based on income (transactions) and interest rates (opportunity cost)
Excess reserves exploded after 2008 QE: Banks held reserves instead of lending, weakening money multiplier link

examples.title: US Money Supply Expansion During COVID-19
examples.description: Federal Reserve responded to COVID crisis with aggressive QE, expanding MB from $3.4T (Feb 2020) to $6.4T (Dec 2020). M2 grew 25% in 2020, fastest since WWII. Initial expectation: would cause inflation. Reality: velocity fell sharply as people/businesses held cash (uncertainty). By 2021-22, velocity normalized while M2 remained high → inflation surge to 9%. Illustrates MV=PY dynamics and velocity variability.
examples.context: Monetary expansion and eventual inflation with lagged effect
examples.data: M2: $15.4T (Feb 2020) → $21.7T (March 2022). M2 velocity fell from 1.4 to 1.1. CPI inflation: 9.1% (June 2022). Fed H.6 data

examples.title: Money Multiplier Calculation
examples.description: Pre-2008 example: Reserve requirement rr = 10% = 0.10. Currency ratio c = 0.4 (public holds $0.40 currency per $1 deposits). Money multiplier: m = (1+c)/(rr+c) = (1+0.4)/(0.1+0.4) = 1.4/0.5 = 2.8. If Fed creates $100B monetary base (via OMO), money supply increases by 2.8 × $100B = $280B. Simple multiplier 1/rr = 10 overstates because currency ratio causes 'leakage' from banking system.
examples.context: Realistic money multiplier with currency drain
examples.data: rr = 0.10, c = 0.4. m = 2.8 (vs simple 1/rr = 10). $100B MB → $280B M1 increase

examples.title: Weimar Republic Hyperinflation (1921-1923)
examples.description: Germany printed money to pay war reparations and government deficits. Money supply increased 1.2 trillion percent. Result: hyperinflation - prices doubled every few days by late 1923. Classic quantity theory: massive M growth → proportional P increase. Velocity also increased (people spent money immediately before it lost value). Mark worthless: $1 = 4.2 trillion marks (Nov 1923). Stabilization required new currency (Rentenmark) backed by real assets.
examples.context: Extreme money supply growth causing hyperinflation
examples.data: Money supply grew 1.2 trillion %. Prices: 1 loaf bread = 200 billion marks (Nov 1923). Exchange: $1 = 4.2T marks

examples.title: Japan's QE and Deflationary Trap (2001-2006, 2013+)
examples.description: Bank of Japan pursued quantitative easing from 2001 (first major central bank to try). Massively expanded monetary base - tripled from 2001-2006. But M2 grew slowly and inflation remained near zero. Why? Money multiplier collapsed - banks sat on excess reserves rather than lending (balance sheet recession, zombie firms, aging population). Illustrates limits of MB expansion when banking system won't transmit to broader money supply.
examples.context: Monetary base expansion with weak transmission to money supply
examples.data: Japan MB: ¥65T (2001) → ¥110T (2006). M2 growth: ~2%/year. Inflation: near 0%. BOJ data

examples.title: US Great Depression - Money Supply Contraction
examples.description: Milton Friedman's monetarist analysis: Fed allowed M1 to fall 35% from 1929-1933. Bank failures destroyed deposits. Fed failed as lender of last resort. Result: severe deflation (-10%/year) and depression. By MV=PY logic: falling M with sticky P led to falling Y (output). Lesson: central bank must prevent money supply collapse during financial crises. Fed learned this lesson by 2008-2009.
examples.data: M1 fell 35% (1929-33). Deflation: 27% total price decline. Unemployment: 25%. Friedman & Schwartz (1963)

content.statement: The money supply represents the total quantity of money circulating in an economy, measured through monetary aggregates (M1, M2) that capture different degrees of liquidity. Understanding how the central bank controls the monetary base and how this translates to broader money supply through the banking system is essential for analyzing monetary policy, inflation, and macroeconomic stability.

explanation.intuition: Think of money supply like water in a plumbing system. The central bank controls the main valve (monetary base) - it can add water by buying bonds (QE) or drain it by selling. But the total water reaching households (M2) depends on the pipes (banking system). Banks multiply the base water through fractional reserve lending - they keep some in tank (reserves) and pump the rest to borrowers, who deposit it in other banks, which lend again. The 'money multiplier' measures how efficiently pipes transmit water. If pipes are clogged (banks unwilling to lend, like 2008-2012), base water doesn't reach households. If pipes are wide open and everyone borrows, base water multiplies many times. The final price level reflects how much water (money) chases available goods.
explanation.key_insight: The crucial insight is that the central bank controls the monetary base directly but not the broader money supply. M1 and M2 depend on: (1) Reserve requirements (how much banks must hold back), (2) Banks' willingness to lend (affected by risk appetite, regulation, loan demand), (3) Public's currency preferences (more cash holding = smaller multiplier), (4) Interest rates on reserves (higher rate = more excess reserves held). The pre-2008 textbook money multiplier of 10 (with 10% reserve requirement) vastly overstated central bank control. Post-2008 with near-zero reserve requirements and interest on reserves, the multiplier has become even more unstable and often less than 1! This is why modern monetary policy focuses on interest rate targeting, not monetary aggregates.
explanation.technical_details: Monetary base: MB = C + R where C = currency, R = reserves. M1 = C + D where D = demand deposits. Money multiplier: m = M1/MB = (C+D)/(C+R). Define c = C/D (currency ratio), rr = R/D (reserve ratio). Then m = (C/D + 1)/((C/D + R/D)) = (c+1)/(c+rr). If c = 0 (all money in banks): m = 1/rr. If rr = 0.1, m = 10. With c = 0.4, rr = 0.1: m = 1.4/0.5 = 2.8. Quantity theory: MV = PY. In logs: m + v = p + y. If v constant: Δm = Δp + Δy. With y at potential: Δm ≈ Δp (money growth = inflation). Money demand: Md = P × L(Y, r) where L_Y > 0 (transactions demand), L_r < 0 (opportunity cost of holding money). Equilibrium: M/P = L(Y, r) determines r given M and Y.

mathematical_formulation.m2_definition: M2 = M1 + Savings + Small time deposits + Retail MMF
mathematical_formulation.simple_money_multiplier: m = 1/rr where rr is required reserve ratio (special case when c=0, overestimates actual multiplier)
mathematical_formulation.realistic_money_multiplier: m = (1+c)/(rr+c) where c = C/D is currency-deposit ratio (reduces to 1/rr when c=0)
mathematical_formulation.equation_of_exchange: MV = PY (Fisher equation) where V = velocity

m1_components.currency: Federal Reserve notes and coins held by public
m1_components.other_checkable_deposits: NOW accounts, ATS accounts, share drafts at credit unions

m2_additions.retail_money_market_funds: Money market mutual funds held by individuals

not_in_m2.institutional_mmf: Money market funds for institutions (were in M3)

central_bank_control.open_market_operations: Fed buys bonds → pays with reserves → MB increases. Fed sells bonds → absorbs reserves → MB decreases
central_bank_control.reserve_requirements: Fed can change rr to affect multiplier (rarely used, now 0%)
central_bank_control.discount_rate: Rate charged to banks borrowing reserves - affects reserve availability
central_bank_control.interest_on_reserves: IOR creates floor for federal funds rate, affects banks' reserve holding decision
central_bank_control.quantitative_easing: Large-scale asset purchases to increase MB when rates at zero

Banking: Reserve management and lending decisions

Treasury management: Cash and liquidity management
